results.title: West wind: the story of Tom Thomson
results.creator_credit: Graham McInnes and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Tom Thomson’s jack pine, painted against a background of lake and sky, has come to symbolize the Canadian North. This film outlines the story of Tom Thomson’s brief life (1877-1917) and career, which began in Toronto, where he worked as a commercial artist. Weekend sketching trips in the country turned into longer journeys farther north, and Thomson finally moved to Algonquin Park, in northern Ontario. When he wasn’t painting and canoeing, he was a park guide. We watch wonderful photography of his favourite landscapes, interspersed with images of the paintings they inspired. Thomson spent less than four years as an artist and was barely 40 when a canoe accident ended his life. Fellow artists Lawren Harris, A.Y. Jackson and Arthur Lismer pay tribute to this genius, who, in Jackson’s words, “contributed more to Canadian painting than any other artist.”
results.title_for_label: West wind: the story of Tom Thomson
results.creator_credit_for_label: Graham McInnes and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Prisoner cast figurines
results.brief_description: Prisoner packed a punch when it premiered in 1979. Set in the fictional suburb of Wentworth, the female-centred prison drama reverberated around the world, spawning international adaptations and a massive cult following.
results.description: Designed and painted by ‘Prisoner: Cell Block H’ fan Greig Chambers and sculpted by Jason Miller. This set, made especially for ACMI Renewal - Moving Australia, includes figurines of characters Bea, Lizzie, Rita, Vera and Joan as well as set pieces: 2 brick wall pieces, 3 sets of bars and 1 prison door. These are not commercially available.
description_for_label: Designed and painted by ‘Prisoner: Cell Block H’ fan Greig Chambers and sculpted by Jason Miller. This set, made especially for ACMI Renewal - Moving Australia, includes figurines of characters Bea, Lizzie, Rita, Vera and Joan as well as set pieces: 2 brick wall pieces, 3 sets of bars and 1 prison door. These are not commercially available.

results.title: The World at war. - Volume 6.
results.creator_credit: Martin Smith, Ted Childs and Thames Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The World at war”.
Part 11: “Red Star” The story of Russia’s massive lonely war with its 20,000,000 military and civilian casualties. A Leningrad housewife who survived the 890 day siege from September 1941, until January 1944 appears in this program. She agrees she was lucky to survive. In her city of three million inhabitants 200,000 people were killed by German shells, a further 630,000 died of cold or starvation. Incredibly the Russians survived and went on to rout the Germans. Part 12: “Whirlwind” The blitz on Britain brings strident public demand for revenge bombing but by the end of 1941 Britain’s force of 700 aircraft is being eaten into by the demands of the North Africa and Atlantic battles. The arrival of Arthur “Bomber” Harris to take charge of Bomber Command heralds a new attitude. Harris is very much in favour of revenge - “They have sowed the wind and now shall reap the whirlwind”, he proclaims publicly. More important, he believes that bombing can, on its own, defeat Germany.

results.title: The World at war. Part 4 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Jeremy Isaacs, Jerome Kuehl and Thames Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World at war”.
Part 24: “The Bomb” The world’s first atomic bomb was dropped on the Japanese city of Hiroshima on August 6, 1945. Four days later a second bomb was dropped on Nagasaki.
Part 25: “Reckoning” The end of the war in Central Europe is a time without pity. The intervention of outsiders from Russia and America means that no European nation can win.
Part 26: “Remember” In the Second World War twenty million Russians died - in action, in captivity, fighting men and women, and ordinary civilians killed in bombing raids. Germany lost nearly five million dead, and two and a half million Japanese died. America lost nearly three hundred thousand men.
Also available on VHS [301619].

results.title: The World at war. Part 5 [DVD]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World at war”.
Hitler’s Germany - this documentary depicts the early years of National Socialism years of optimism, economic recovery, and political terror; also shows how the nation dealt with day-to-day life in Hitler’s Germany. The “Two deaths of Hitler” addresses the mystery surrounding Hitler’s death. “The Final Solution” examines the growth of the Nazi racial doctrines from their origins to 1939 and the subsequent systemic murder of civilians.

results.title: The World at war. Part 3 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Jeremy Isaacs, John Pett, Martin Smith, Michael Parton, Peter Batty, Philip Whitehead and Thames Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World at war”.
Part 16: “Inside the Third Reich” In the summer of 1940 the German forces are the conquerors of Western Europe, and the sense in Germany is that the war is over. Part 17: “Morning” In the early morning of 5 June 1944, the largest amphibian invasion force ever gathered reaches the beaches of Normandy. Part 18: “Occupation” The Netherlands, a neutral country, is attacked without warning in 1940 and capitulates. Part 19: “Pincers” With the liberation of Paris on August 25, 1944, the war seems to be as good as over. The American plans advance on a broad front. Part 20: “Genocide” Addresses the essentials of Nazism in regards to philosophy, politics and race. Part 21: “Nemesis” Thousands die as the RAF and USAF attack by night and day. Allied prisoners-of-war are released by their advancing comrades, while German soldiers are captured by the thousands. Part 22: “Japan 1941-1945” Japan continues to defend the homeland, unaware of the terrible weapon to be used against them. Part 23: “Pacific” The Allied Pacific offensive comes under the command of two rivals: General MacArthur, sweeping upwards from the Solomons and New Guinea to the Philippines, and Admiral Nimitz, in the Gilberts at Tarawa. Also available on VHS [301628], [301629], [301630], [301631].
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jeremy Isaacs, John Pett, Martin Smith, Michael Parton, Peter Batty, Philip Whitehead and Thames Television

results.title: The World at war. Part 2 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Jeremy Isaacs, John Pett, Martin Smith, Philip Whitehead, Ted Childs and Thames Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World at war”.
Part 8: “Desert: The war in North Africa” The Germans are driven from North Africa but target Italy. Part 9: “Stalingrad” The German Army is defeated at Stalingrad. Part 10: “Wolfpack” Germany attempts to starve Britain by attacking ships bringing supplies from North America. Part 11: “Red Star” The story of Russia’s massive lonely war with its 20,000,000 military and civilian casualties. Part 12: “Whirlwind” The blitz on Britain brings strident public demand for revenge. Part 13: “Tough Old Gut” Winston Churchill describes Italy to Stalin as the “soft underbelly of the crocodile”. It is his arguments that persuade the Americans to join the Allies. Part 14: “It’s a Lovely Day Tomorrow” Monsoonal conditions for five months of every year and disease make the lot of the Burma Army “just another nightmare”. Europeans find jungle conditions alien and the Japanese ability to not only endure but to thrive in the same circumstances helps build a “superman” myth among the Allied soldiers. Part 15: “Homefires” After the defeat in the Battle of Britain, the Luftwaffe changes the direction of their bombing raids from London to provincial cities. Also available on VHS [301586], [301623], [301621], [301625], [301628].
